title: How to Prepare Ribs for Grilling

steps.headline: Take your ribs out of the packaging and set them on a cutting board.
steps.description: Put a clean cutting board on a flat surface, like a countertop or table. Unwrap your ribs from their plastic or wax paper packaging and set them on your cutting board. Throw away the packaging as soon as you take the ribs out to avoid contaminating other parts of your kitchen with raw meat.

steps.headline: Flip the ribs over so the membrane is facing upwards.
steps.description: The membrane is the thin, pink lining on the back of the ribs. Flip the ribs over so that you can see the individual rib bones covered by meat and a membrane. You can wear gloves to protect your hands if you’d like to, or you can wash your hands directly after handling the ribs.

steps.headline: Peel the membrane off of the ribs with your fingers.
steps.description: Grab the end of the membrane with your hand and gently pull it up and away from the ribs in one piece. Continue all the way down the length of your ribs until you have fully removed the membrane.Tip: If you are having a hard time removing the membrane, your butcher may have taken it off already. It is important to remove the membrane because it won’t cook down in the oven or on the grill, so it can make your ribs chewy and tough. If you have a hard time gripping the membrane, cover your fingers with a paper towel for extra friction.

steps.headline: Trim off any loose pieces or large fatty areas.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to carefully remove any thin edges on the meat that might char on the grill or extra pieces of membrane. If there are large areas of fat on the ends of your ribs, you can cut those off as well. Try to make your ribs uniform so they will cook evenly. It is important to remove large fatty areas so that your ribs are less chewy. You can save any large chunks of meat or fat and put them into a stew.

steps.headline: Season your ribs with a dry spice rub to add flavor easily.
steps.description: Combine salt, pepper, and any spices you’d like to add to your spice rub in an airtight container. Shake them up to combine all of your ingredients and sprinkle them over both sides of your ribs in a thin, even coating.Tip: To make a standard spice rub, combine 1 tbsp (6 g) of ground cumin, 1 tbsp (8 g) of chili powder, 1 tbsp (6.8 g) of paprika, and a sprinkle of salt and pepper. If you have any leftover spice rub, store it in an airtight container for future ribs.

steps.headline: Marinate your ribs to add moisture and flavor.
steps.description: If you want to soak your ribs in additional flavor, cover them in a marinade of your choice with a basting brush. Pour your leftover marinade in the oven-safe dish or slow cooker to let your ribs cook in the flavors. To make a honey glazed marinade, combine ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of soy sauce, ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of whiskey, ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of honey, 2 tablespoons (6 g) of grated ginger, 1 1/2 teaspoons (2 g) of white pepper, 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of sesame oil, 1/2 teaspoon (4 g) of ground cinnamon, and 1/4 teaspoon (0.25 g) of grated nutmeg.

steps.headline: Place your ribs in the fridge overnight so they can absorb more flavor.
steps.description: If you want to leave your spice rub or marinade on your ribs to let it soak in, wrap your ribs in plastic or foil and set them in the fridge for 8 hours or overnight. This allows the meat to soak in the flavors and spices for a more thorough flavor profile.

steps.headline: Wrap your ribs in aluminum foil.
steps.description: Move your ribs from the cutting board to a layer of foil and wrap them up completely. Make sure the foil covers every part of the ribs so that they don’t get burned. Cooking foil protects the delicate top layer of meat from the intense heat of the oven.

steps.headline: Bake the ribs at 275 °F (135 °C) for 3 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Ribs cook the best at a low temperature for a long amount of time. Keep your ribs in the oven for 3 to 4 hours or until the meat feels tender.Tip: Turning the temperature on your oven up might make the ribs cook faster, but they won’t be as moist or tender.

steps.headline: Take your ribs out of the oven and remove the foil wrap.
steps.description: Heat up your grill before you remove the ribs from the oven so that they don’t cool down. Take off the cooking foil before you finish them up on the grill. Foil works well in the oven but it will prevent your ribs from getting a nice char if you use it on the grill.

parts.name: Using a Slow Cooker Before Grilling Ribs

steps.headline: Stack your ribs in a slow cooker.
steps.description: Transfer your ribs from the cutting board to your slow cooker. You can stack them on top of each other. Make sure the lid can close on your slow cooker so that it traps in the heat. If your ribs are too long for the slow cooker, consider cutting them in half so that they fit.

steps.headline: Set your slow cooker on LOW and let the ribs cook for 6 to 8 hours.
steps.description: Set your slow cooker to the lowest setting that it has. Leave your ribs inside for 6 to 8 hours while you are at work or school. Leave the heat down low so your ribs stay moist and tender. Turning your slow cooker on too high can dry out your ribs and make them less tender.

steps.headline: Take the ribs out of the slow cooker right before you grill them.
steps.description: Once your grill is heated up, turn off your slow cooker and gently pull the ribs out. Don’t let them sit out or cool down before you move to the grill to finish them off.Tip: Since your ribs are cooked fully from the slow cooker, feel free to sample the meat before you put them on the grill.

steps.headline: Cover the ribs with BBQ sauce for extra moisture and flavor, if desired.
steps.description: Set your ribs on a cutting board on a flat surface. Use a basting brush to apply a generous amount of BBQ sauce to both sides of your ribs.Tip: You can make your own BBQ sauce by combining 1/2 cup (115 g) of ketchup, 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of water, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of maple syrup, 2 teaspoons (10 g) of Dijon mustard, 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of Worcestershire sauce, 1 teaspoon (4.5 g) of butter, and your own spices to taste.

steps.headline: Grill your ribs for 3 to 4 minutes until the outside is caramelized.
steps.description: Place your ribs on the grill over direct high heat. Grill them for 3 to 4 minutes or until the meat starts to fall off the bone. Check the internal temperature with a meat thermometer to make sure your ribs are at 145 °F (63 °C) before taking them off the grill. Grilling the ribs at the last minute makes the outside extra crispy and the BBQ sauce taste more caramelized.

steps.headline: Enjoy your ribs while they’re warm.
steps.description: Take your ribs off the grill and serve them immediately. You can eat them on their own or pair them with mashed potatoes and a nice salad, or some collard greens and roasted vegetables. You probably won’t even need silverware to eat your ribs since the meat will fall right off the bone!
